<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 291]]<|/det|>
9702/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 128, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>Data</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 106, 599, 123]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{ m s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 138, 640, 155]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{ m s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 170, 630, 186]]<|/det|>
elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{-19} \text{ C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 201, 635, 218]]<|/det|>
unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{ u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 233, 635, 250]]<|/det|>
rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 265, 635, 281]]<|/det|>
rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \text{ kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 295, 650, 312]]<|/det|>
Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 326, 635, 343]]<|/det|>
molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{ J K}^{-1} \text{ mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 357, 650, 373]]<|/det|>
Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{-23} \text{ J K}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 388, 690, 405]]<|/det|>
gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11} \text{ N m}^2 \text{ kg}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 419, 660, 436]]<|/det|>
permittivity of free space \(\varepsilon_0 = 8.85 \times 10^{-12} \text{ F m}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 437, 650, 467]]<|/det|>
\[(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 481, 636, 497]]<|/det|>
Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{-34} \text{ J s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 512, 688, 529]]<|/det|>
Stefan–Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \text{ W m}^{-2} \text{ K}^{-4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 570, 171, 585]]<|/det|>
<form>Formulae</form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 603, 560, 619]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^2\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 620, 583, 638]]<|/det|>
\[\nu^2 = u^2 + 2as\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 653, 552, 669]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p = \rho g \Delta h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 684, 544, 700]]<|/det|>
upthrust \(F = \rho g V\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 720, 560, 746]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_0 = \frac{f_s V}{V \pm V_s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 765, 560, 781]]<|/det|>
electric current \(I = \text{Anvq}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 797, 611, 813]]<|/det|>
resistors in series \(R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 828, 618, 855]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_2} + \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 151, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 72, 490, 89]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by a vector quantity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
A sphere falls vertically through a liquid that has density \(830 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\). The sphere has radius \(r\) and constant velocity \(v\), as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[291, 205, 705, 386]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 402, 532, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 434, 181, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 434, 603, 453]]<|/det|>
The drag force \(D\) acting on the sphere is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 464, 544, 482]]<|/det|>
\[D = 6\pi r\eta \nu\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
where \(\eta\) is a property of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 526, 473, 544]]<|/det|>
Determine the SI base units of \(\eta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 712, 920, 730]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 743, 180, 761]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 743, 918, 777]]<|/det|>
State an equation showing the relationship between the magnitudes of the weight \(W,\) drag force \(D\) and upthrust \(U\) acting on the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 789, 920, 808]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 722, 89]]<|/det|>
The volume of the sphere is \(4.6 \text{cm}^3\). The drag force \(D\) is \(0.32 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 484, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the weight of the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[509, 286, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
<form>weight = ....................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 317, 920, 335]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 153, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 72, 316, 88]]<|/det|>
Define momentum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 149, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 197]]<|/det|>
A child stands on a scooter on horizontal ground. The combined mass of the child and the scooter is \(16\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
The child starts from rest and pushes once on the ground with her foot which causes her to accelerate. The push lasts for a time of 1.1 s. The speed of the child and the scooter after the push is \(0.60\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Determine the average resultant force acting horizontally on the child and the scooter during the push.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 393, 920, 410]]<|/det|>
<form>average force = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 424, 141, 442]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 424, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
Later, the child in **(b)** travels down a slope at a constant angle to the horizontal, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 465, 732, 650]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 670, 591, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 700, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
At point A her speed is \(0.60\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\). She has a constant acceleration of \(0.85\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-2}\) parallel to the slope. After a time of 3.7 s, she reaches point B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 747, 761, 765]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance \(x\) travelled by the child along the slope from A to B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 920, 920, 937]]<|/det|>
<form>x =  .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
At point B, the child in **(c)** applies the brake with a constant force to maintain a constant velocity. Point C is \(18 \text{m}\) from point B, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 112, 855, 262]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 299, 670, 318]]<|/det|>
The work done by the braking force between B and C is 250 J.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 331, 181, 349]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 330, 574, 349]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the braking force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 469, 920, 488]]<|/det|>
<form>force = ....................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 501, 180, 519]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 500, 920, 534]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.3, sketch the variation of the kinetic energy of the child and scooter with distance travelled from point A to point C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 530, 628, 549]]<|/det|>
Numerical values for kinetic energy are not required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 556, 752, 870]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 876, 532, 895]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 892, 917, 910]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 924, 920, 942]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 72, 153, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 71, 710, 89]]<|/det|>
The variation of stress with strain for a metal P is shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 100, 730, 350]]<|/det|>

Point E is the elastic limit of the metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 180, 445]]<|/det|>

Label this point Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 148, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 71, 685, 89]]<|/det|>
State the conditions necessary for an object to be in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 918, 123]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 918, 158]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 195, 146, 213]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 194, 880, 213]]<|/det|>
A wire is used to hold a uniform shelf AB horizontally in equilibrium as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 222, 806, 465]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 480, 591, 499]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 511, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
The wire is connected to the midpoint of shelf AB at an angle of \(50^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The shelf is attached to a wall by a hinge at A. The length of shelf AB is \(0.65 \text{m}\) and its weight is \(33 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 558, 920, 591]]<|/det|>
A cup of weight \(1.5 \text{N}\) rests on the shelf with its centre of gravity at a horizontal distance of \(0.12 \text{m}\) from B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 606, 183, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 605, 707, 624]]<|/det|>
By taking moments about A, determine the tension in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 806, 920, 824]]<|/det|>
<form>tension = ....................................................... N [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 175, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 504, 88]]<|/det|>
The stress in the wire is \(1.5 \times 10^{7} \text{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 465, 120]]<|/det|>
Determine the radius of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 243, 920, 261]]<|/det|>
<form>radius = ....................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 276, 180, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 275, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
More items are added to the shelf, doubling the stress in the wire. The wire is made of the metal P from (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 322, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 3.1 to state and explain whether the wire will behave plastically or elastically as the stress doubles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 491, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 522, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 149, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
With reference to the direction of transfer of energy, compare the oscillations of transverse and longitudinal progressive waves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 212, 920, 229]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 241, 146, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 241, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
A pipe is open at one end and closed at the other with a piston. The piston can slide freely and is at a distance of \(4.5 \times 10^{-2} \text{m}\) from the open end of the pipe.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
A loudspeaker is positioned near the open end of the pipe and emits a sound wave of a single constant frequency. A stationary wave is formed in the pipe, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 331, 836, 540]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 555, 534, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 183, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 586, 667, 604]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 4.1, draw a letter A at the position of an antinode.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 586, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 616, 181, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 616, 512, 635]]<|/det|>
The speed of sound in air is \(340 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 648, 561, 666]]<|/det|>
Determine the frequency of the sound wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 833, 920, 851]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = .................................................... Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 833, 920, 851]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The piston is moved to the left. The frequency of the sound wave emitted by the loudspeaker is then changed so that a stationary wave is formed with same number of antinodes as in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 843, 151]]<|/det|>
State and explain the change that is made to the frequency of the sound wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 269, 920, 286]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

Define electric potential difference (p.d.).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 131, 918, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
A power supply, three resistors and a component X are connected in the circuit shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 205, 675, 408]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 421, 532, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 451, 920, 488]]<|/det|>
The power supply has an electromotive force (e.m.f.) of \(230\mathrm{V}\) and negligible internal resistance. The current in the power supply is \(7.0\mathrm{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 180, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 500, 376, 518]]<|/det|>
Identify component X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[855, 530, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 560, 181, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 560, 740, 579]]<|/det|>
Show that the p.d. across the resistor of resistance \(0.86 \Omega\) is \(6.0 \text{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[870, 655, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 685, 181, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 685, 403, 704]]<|/det|>
Determine the current \(I_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 808, 920, 828]]<|/det|>
<form>I_{1} = .................................................... A

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 810, 938, 828]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 72, 175, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

Before the \(\alpha\) -decay, P is travelling at a constant velocity. After the decay, Q has a velocity of \(1.3 \times 10^{5} \text{ m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(68^{\circ}\) to the original path of P.
